question: List all the different temperatures that a user has cooked onions.

events.method: brief finish on surface of pan (sear/pan finish)
events.outcome: nice color and doneness

evidence.excerpt: and then I briefly took it to 180° on the surface of the pan just to give it some nice color and done ness

events.outcome: Sauce was OK but almost none of the onion flavor came through (muted aroma/flavor).

evidence.excerpt: I put them in a sous vide in about 165 with some butter and then I put that through a sieve and I mixed it in with some egg and mustard and it was OK but like the taste was OK but almost none of the onion flavor came out

events.outcome: Sauce thickened nicely to hold shape, flavor improved slightly, onion flavor remained too subtle

evidence.excerpt: gently heating the sauce to around 140-152°F, which thickened it nicely to hold shape, improved flavor slightly, but left the onion too subtle

events.outcome: Held flavor and smell well after freezing (manually vacuumed Ziploc) for ~4+ days and ~24 hours refrigeration defrost

evidence.excerpt: I froze some caramelized onions and I had them in the freezer in a manually vacuumed Ziploc bag for about maybe four or more days opened it up and the flavor and smell was pretty good and that was after about 24 hours of refrigeration defrost

events.outcome: Added Kerrygold butter and ~2 tbsp water to slow burning and more evenly distribute heat

evidence.excerpt: i’ve added some keri gold butter and water probably about 2 tablespoons on the first round and then I just did it again ... temperatures are still around 229° when I checked it and it could’ve been that way for up to a half an hour around then

events.method: sous vide (bags with caramelized onions; >6 hours overnight, after caramelizing ~2 hours)
events.outcome: Too loose; did not smell or taste very good

evidence.excerpt: both of the bags with caramelized onions were put in sous vide for about more than six hours overnight. One was cooked at 141.5° the other one was cooked at 1:45.5°.

events.method: sous vide (bags with caramelized onions; >6 hours overnight, after caramelizing ~2 hours)
events.outcome: Much thicker; flavor and smell were nicer

evidence.excerpt: both of the bags with caramelized onions were put in sous vide for about more than six hours overnight. One was cooked at 141.5° the other one was cooked at 1:45.5°.

events.method: rough cutting (radial vertical cut) in preparation for caramelization

evidence.excerpt: rough cutting some organic yellow onions before caramelization. The RADIAL vertical cut around the center

events.temperature: steaming / low heat (steam started from a few milliliters of water)
events.method: placed in a pot with a very small amount of water to generate steam

evidence.excerpt: place the onions in a pot because I didn’t have a lid big enough for a pan and placed just maybe at most a few milliliters not a few milliliters of a very tiny amount of water in the bottom of the pan just enough to start some steam

events.temperature: steaming / boiling at the bottom (pot mostly on the heat for ~20 minutes)
events.method: steaming in a pot with simmer/boil at the bottom
events.outcome: onions became somewhat translucent and pliable after ~20 minutes

evidence.excerpt: after about 20 minutes with the pot mostly on the heat and steaming and boiling at the bottom there appears to be more liquid and the onions are somewhat translucent pliable

events.method: longer at a lower temperature for hollandaise mix (as stated)

evidence.excerpt: OK for this next round of caramelized onion hollandaise sauce ... Going to be this time for longer at a lower temperature about 141°

events.outcome: After ~4 hours the mix tasted okay but was grainy/coarse; flavor improved significantly by ~10 hours.

evidence.excerpt: cooking at 145 degrees egg blended with caramelized onions. sous about 4 hours

events.outcome: Cooked for about another hour at 142.5°F; avocado oil increased onion sweetness; combined preparations retained distinguishable flavors (e.g., salmon remained identifiable).

evidence.excerpt: i cooked all three for about another hour and 142.5°. Adding the avocado oil really brought out the sweetness in the onion.

events.outcome: added to jar with egg yolks and honey

evidence.excerpt: the first video is me putting the caramelized onions and egg yolks for a little bit of honey in a jar.

events.method: jar placed in a water bath
events.outcome: warmed/held in water bath with egg yolks/honey

evidence.excerpt: sounds like you're making sweet hollandaise with caramelized onions, egg yolks, and honey in a jar on a 141°F water bath.

events.outcome: turning it down

evidence.excerpt: I’m caramelizing some onions. They’ve been cooking about 40 minutes; the pan’s surface temperature has ranged 160–200°F, which is a bit high, so I’m turning it down.

events.outcome: gonna turn it down

evidence.excerpt: I’m caramelizing some onions. ... Temperature of the pan goes between 160 and 200. That’s a little too high so I’m gonna turn it down.
Lower the heat to low or medium-low ... If you’re at 160–200°C, try closer to low heat and adjust as needed.

events.outcome: turning the heat down

evidence.excerpt: Got it — you’ve been caramelizing onions for about 40 minutes, with the pan around 160–200°C, and you’re turning the heat down.
Getting the pan right ... when I have the pan set to the LO setting ... the surface temperature of the pan gets hotter. It’s 213°.
Got it — you’re trying to dial in heat on a heavy pan while caramelizing onions, and the surface is around 213° even on LO.

events.outcome: gonna turn it down

evidence.excerpt: I’m caramelizing some onions. They’ve probably been cooking for about. I don’t know maybe 40 minutes surface. Temperature of the pan goes between 160 and 200. That’s a little too high so I’m gonna turn it down.

events.outcome: Thick, jam-like (not quite jammy), dark orange, holds shape, somewhat viscous and smooth; onion flavor pronounced and could use salt.

evidence.excerpt: It was sous vide in a Ziploc bag at 145.5° for about three hours.

events.outcome: Previously caramelized onions that had been frozen prior to the sous vide step.

evidence.excerpt: The previous image shows what caramelized onions, previously caramelized onions that were previously frozen...

events.outcome: Pan side temperature climbed to 278°F as moisture released/foamed; user planned to reduce heat.

evidence.excerpt: see yeah as there is started to get more foam the temperature the side of the pan reached to 78 278 it reached 278° and so I think that is one of the dangers as it starts to leak out moisture the temperature climbs very quickly so I’m gonna reduce the heat

events.method: sous vide (onion previously caramelized, then vacuum/sea l jar)
events.outcome: Caramelized onion (with egg yolk) held in sous vide for ~15 hours

evidence.excerpt: The onion and egg the caramelized onion and egg yolk has been in the sous vide for about 15 hours at 139.5°

events.method: braising / long simmer (in the red-wine braise)
events.outcome: Onion cooked as part of the braise for about three hours (sauce still heavy/greasy)

evidence.excerpt: even after cooking for about three hours it’s still really heavy and the sweetness of the wine...

events.outcome: Onions were caramelized (browned) before being placed in the sous vide

evidence.excerpt: The onion and egg the caramelized onion and egg yolk has been in the sous vide...

events.outcome: sauce got pretty thick; onion and egg flavor remained subtle

evidence.excerpt: I put it on about 145° pan and it got pretty thick but the onion and egg tastes was really subtle

events.method: held at ~143°F then sieved into a pan
events.outcome: viscosity high enough to hold a streak; emulsified but a little watery; tastes pretty good

evidence.excerpt: after being in a after being at about 143° the egg onion hollandaise sauce ... it taste pretty good

events.method: heated the pan up to ~152° briefly
events.outcome: brief heating noticeably thickened the sauce

evidence.excerpt: I heated the pan up about 152° very briefly taking it on and off the heat ... that has noticeably thickened up the sauce

events.outcome: sauce thickened to hold shape; onion flavor still a little too subtle

evidence.excerpt: trying to keep it at around 140° and that has noticeably thickened up the sauce ... The Onion is a little too subtle

events.outcome: Onions don’t caramelize very well when temp drops below ~180°F

evidence.excerpt: if the temperature drops below about 180° then the caramel then the onions don’t seem to caramelize very well

events.outcome: User is trying to hold the pan in this range for caramelization; difficult to maintain

evidence.excerpt: but it’s difficult to keep the panin the 180 to 200 range

events.outcome: Some onions begin to brown while others remain pale/translucent

evidence.excerpt: I think it was around 184° this you can see from the photo that some of the onions begin to get brown while others stay more translucent, pale yellow

events.outcome: Some parts of the pan exceed 200°, causing uneven browning and risk of burning

evidence.excerpt: in this photo, some parts of the pan are over 200°

events.outcome: caramelized; spread on challah toast

evidence.excerpt: I had sous vide eggs and caramelized onions for eight hours no for about 10 hours and then I spread it on the challah toast

events.method: pan (lid removed after reaching this temperature)
events.outcome: starting to become a little translucent; shrunk slightly

evidence.excerpt: cooking at about 182 degrees onions are starting to become a little translucent and I think they have shrunk just a little bit. I removed the pot lid

events.outcome: steam present and a little bit of sizzling; not translucent

evidence.excerpt: checking the temperature of the onions after the after they’ve been cooking with the lid on. There’s some steam and a little bit of sizzling but not quite translucent at all

events.outcome: onions became much more brown at times

evidence.excerpt: The onions have become much more brown at times they were cooking at about 210° but then I turned the heat down on average it’s been around 180°

events.outcome: average cooking temperature after turning heat down

evidence.excerpt: on average it’s been around 180°

events.outcome: was on low heat (~165°) before turning the dial up

evidence.excerpt: it was around and I think it was maybe around 165° so then I turned up the heat a little bit from maybe like 2 to 4 on the dial

events.outcome: significant browning in some pieces while others remained translucent

evidence.excerpt: it started to go up to like 270 or somewhere in the 270° range and as you can see there’s significant browning in some of the pieces and still translucent and not very brown in some of the larger pieces

events.outcome: translucent, pliable, extra liquid

evidence.excerpt: translucent, pliable, and extra liquid after 20 minutes of steaming.

events.outcome: faint sizzling; water dumped to allow direct contact

evidence.excerpt: starting to hear the right kind of sizzle on the pan ... I think about 190° and I can hear some faint sizzling

events.outcome: inconsistent browning (pan too hot)

evidence.excerpt: The pan had gotten up to about 232° and it was causing inconsistent browning.

events.outcome: still causes browning around this range; stirring roughly every minute

evidence.excerpt: Even at a lower temperature once it’s about 200° or probably around 205° anything about that...

events.outcome: significant browning and softening

evidence.excerpt: I ... cooked it on 375° for maybe three hours ... I covered it up in foil ... And there was a significant browning and softening

events.outcome: nice browning during the lower-heat pan phase

evidence.excerpt: I started out at around 220° and that had some nice browning I had to stir probably about every couple minutes and add a little splash of water

events.outcome: deep brown color from frying

evidence.excerpt: I really kicked it up the heat to about between 280 and around 300° ... that really started because the deep deep brown color was basically happened when it was frying

events.outcome: caramelized (sous vide) for ~4–5 hours

evidence.excerpt: This had been in a sous vide circulator at about 140.5° for maybe 4 to 5 hours.

events.outcome: reheating after refrigeration

events.outcome: reduced pan heat while cooking

events.outcome: eggs cooked a little; onion mixture scooped in

events.outcome: eggs cooked a little; pan temp ~140° while working

evidence.excerpt: and 140° range of a pan was a little bit hot

events.outcome: brief spike to 150°F; then cooked at ~150°F and thickened nicely

evidence.excerpt: I actually let it cook at around 150° on the on the surface temperature of the pan and it actually with enough speed in motion it thickened up pretty nicely

events.temperature: medium heat (not specified explicitly; implied by 'onions met butter')

evidence.excerpt: tasting the air as onions met butter;

events.method: pan on stovetop, covered with lid

evidence.excerpt: putting the onions with the pan in the pan on a stove top and covering it with a lid

events.temperature: unspecified (added water and oil in a pan)
events.method: onions placed in a pan; water and oil added

evidence.excerpt: putting some onions in a pan then adding water and oil

events.outcome: Significant moisture and steam released when lid opened

evidence.excerpt: Opened up the the pan from the lid that had a covered lid of sauteing onions when I had the temperature around 176°. I opened it up and there was significance amount of moisture and steam coming out

events.outcome: After ~30 minutes onions more translucent with some browning on smaller pieces

evidence.excerpt: This is a picture of the onions ... maybe 30 minutes they're starting to get more translucent noticeable some browning ... the temperature is about 185° on the pan

events.method: covered in heavy-bottom pan with lid

evidence.excerpt: Sliced up some onions ... Temperature initial temperature was about 92° as measured by an infrared thermometer. Then I covered with a lid. Around 12:16 p.m.

events.outcome: no visible change (no steam, almost nothing happened)

evidence.excerpt: Checked on the onions that were covered in a pan The temperature is about 140° and after it is now 10:27 so after about maybe 10 minutes almost nothing happened because it was just too cold there was there's basically no change no steam no nothing

events.method: small pan with butter (stirring over ~20 minutes)
events.outcome: foamed then browned; produced a sweet, nutty butter after straining

evidence.excerpt: I diced up some onions and put it in a small pan and try to keep the temperature to about 250° ... over about 20 minutes it first starts to foam heavily ... it gets brown almost like it’s frying ... the after result is a pretty sweet very nutty butter once it’s strained.

events.method: sous vide in a Ziploc bag
events.outcome: after ~21–22 hours, not noticeably brown overall; a few very brown spots

evidence.excerpt: I put raw onions in a Ziploc bag and sous vide at around 183° it’s been cooking for about probably 21 to 22 hours ... not noticeably brown there’s also a few onions which are the very brown spots

events.method: larger batch in butter on high heat
events.outcome: burned the onions

evidence.excerpt: the temperature ended up getting at some point around 320° I think more than once in a larger batch of onions and butter and that just burned it.

events.method: pan on much higher heat (electric burner)
events.outcome: sides of pan reached ~270° and there were burnt parts in the onions

evidence.excerpt: I put it on a much much higher heat the sides of the pan got up to about 270 but then they started to be burnt parts in the onions

events.method: electric burner / larger pan (attempt to get temperature above 200°)
events.outcome: temperature jumps quickly after moisture loss, making control difficult

evidence.excerpt: you have to be really really diligent because you have to keep it on a really high ... to begin with to get it over 200° but then it quickly jump in heat

events.method: sous vide / stovetop (user refers to 'high' or 'very high' heat)
events.outcome: water level dropped during sous vide because of high heat; uneven browning

evidence.excerpt: it takes quite a while and in a very high heat at some point I think it stopped because the water got too low because it’s on such a high heat

events.outcome: softened; maintained some texture/crunch (overall outcome described after second step)

evidence.excerpt: softened for about an hour at low temperature around 180 degrees

events.method: heat increased to higher temperature for browning (~15 minutes)
events.outcome: crunchy with spots of brown around edges; larger pieces translucent white; browned flavor

evidence.excerpt: kicked up to around 300 degrees for about 15 minutes

events.outcome: caramelized onions
